::: notes - Watches the workflow and skips steps (targets) whose code, data & upstream dependencies have not changed. - When all targets are up to date, evidence that results match the code. - Trust results. - Confirm computation is reproducible ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Code walkthrough

If you want to follow along in your local R environment, you can clone the repository at this link:
[[https://github.com/JT-39/targets-coffee-code-walkthrough]({{< env url_code_walkthrough_git >}}){target="_blank"}]{.link-underlined} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Setup

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("targets") ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Create an R project

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} usethis::create_project(path = r"(C:\Users\jtufts\Documents\targets-demo)") ``` :::
::: callout-tip

More information here: [[https://github.com/JT-39/dau-R-template-ext]({{< env url_dauR_template >}}){target="_blank"}]{.link-underlined}
::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Develop your data pipeline

The project directory could look something like...
``` {.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} â”œâ”€â”€ analysis.R â”œâ”€â”€ _data/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ raw_data.csv â”œâ”€â”€ R/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ functions.R ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Absence data
![](_images/absence_data.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## analysis.R
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} source(here::here("R/functions.R")) # Path to absence data absence_data_file_path <- here::here("_data/1_absence_3term_nat_reg_la.csv") # Extract national absence and format date df_nat_absence <- get_nat_absence_data(absence_data_file_path) |> format_time_period() # Fit a linear model model <- fit_model(df_nat_absence) # Plot the data and model plot_model(model, df_nat_absence) ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## functions.R
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Pull national absence from file get_nat_absence_data <- function(file_path) { read.csv(file = file_path) |> dplyr::filter(geographic_level == "National") } # Extract the start year from academic year extract_year <- function(date) { paste0(substr(date, 1, 4)) } # Format the year as a date format_time_period <- function(data) { data |> dplyr::mutate(Date = lubridate::year(as.Date(extract_year(time_period), format = "%Y")), .after=time_period) } # Fit the model and pull coefficients fit_model <- function(data) { lm(sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact ~ Date, data) |> coefficients() } # Round to the nearets multiple of five round_to_multiple_five <- function(x) { ceiling((x + 1)/5)*5 } # Plot the data and model plot_model <- function(model, data) { ggplot2::ggplot(data) + ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = Date, y = sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact, colour = school_type)) + ggplot2::geom_line(ggplot2::aes(x = Date, y = sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact, colour = school_type)) + ggplot2::scale_colour_manual(values = kasstylesr::color_picker(4), breaks = c("Total", "State-funded primary", "State-funded secondary", "Special")) + ggplot2::geom_abline(intercept = model[1], slope = model[2], show.legend = T, colour="red", linetype="dashed") + ggplot2::annotate("text", x = max(data$Date), y = lm(sess_overall_percent_pa_10_exact ~ Date, df_nat_absence) |> fitted.values() |> max(), hjust = -0.45, label = "Line of best fit", colour = "red") + ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(breaks = scales::pretty_breaks(), limits = function(x) { c(0, round_to_multiple_five(max(x))) }) + ggplot2::coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + ggplot2::theme_minimal() + kasstylesr::kas_style() + ggplot2::labs( title = "Average persistent absence over time in England", subtitle = "Split by school type. Only includes persistent absentees.", x = "", y = "Overall absence rate (%)", colour = "School type:" ) } ``` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Outputs
::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} model[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (Intercept) 12.6906 ``` ::: ```{.r .cell-code} model[2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Date 0.0004374435 ``` ::: :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Outputs ![](./_outputs/ab_plot.png){width="70%" height="70%"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Now make a [{targets}]{style="color:#4758AB;"} pipeline

``` {.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} â”œâ”€â”€ _targets_analysis.R* â”œâ”€â”€ _data/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ raw_data.csv â”œâ”€â”€ R/ â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ functions.R ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Create a [{targets}]{style="color:#4758AB;"} template
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_script() ``` :::
![](_images/tar_script.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## There are 3 parts to the pipeline
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} 1. Packages are loaded ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(targets) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} 2. Pipeline-specific options are set ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_option_set(packages = "utils") tar_source(here::here("R/functions.R")) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} 3. The pipeline itself, a list of *targets* ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} list( tar_target(name = data, command = data.frame(x = sample.int(100), y = sample.int(100))), tar_target(name = data_summary, command = summarize_data(data)) ) ``` ::: :::
::: notes - Due to the execution of the pipeline in parallel, load packages used in pipeline seperately. - So the pkgs are available to all workers. - At the top of the script, think â€œpipeline infrastructureâ€ packages ({targets} and some others). - Inside tar_option_set() think â€œfunctions that run inside the pipelineâ€ packages. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The [{targets}]{style="color:#4758AB;"} pipeline

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - It is simply a list of *targets* ğŸ¯ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - A target is defined using `tar_target()` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Each has 2 necessary inputs - `name` - `command` \~ the function that generates the target :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The [{targets}]{style="color:#4758AB;"} pipeline
::: fragment So... a target defined as: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_target(name = y, command = f(x)) ``` ::: :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in} Can be understood as: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} y <- f(x) ``` ::: :::
::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Targets after this can use the output of previous targets :::
::: notes - A target is really just a step in the analysis pipeline ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## The [{targets}]{style="color:#4758AB;"} pipeline
![](./_images/targets_pipeline.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Build the pipeline ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_make() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` > dispatched target data_file o completed target data_file [0.55 seconds] > dispatched target nat_data o completed target nat_data [0.71 seconds] > dispatched target nat_data_clean o completed target nat_data_clean [0.01 seconds] > dispatched target model o completed target model [0 seconds] Saving 7 x 7 in image > dispatched target plot o completed target plot [0.81 seconds] > ended pipeline [2.29 seconds] ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-up} ::: callout-tip
Use the code below to set which script the {`target`} functions default to: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_config_set(script = "src/_targets_analysis.R") ``` :::
::: ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## An empty global environment?
![](_images/empty_environment.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## What is going on?

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} creates a pipeline of pure functions ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Running the pipeline does not depend on the global environment ğŸŒ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - It also does not change anything outside its scope ğŸ”­ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - The pipeline is **PURE** :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## \_targets/

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - The outputs are stored in `_targets/objects/` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Each target is saved as an object in the `.rds` format ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - So, you **MUST** add `_targets/` to `.gitignore` (for GitHub) â˜ï¸ :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## \_targets/
``` {.bash .code code-line-numbers="false"} _targets/ â”œâ”€â”€ meta â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ meta â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ process â”‚ â””â”€â”€ progress â”œâ”€â”€ objects â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ model â”‚ â”œâ”€â”€ nat_data â”‚ â””â”€â”€ nat_data_clean â””â”€â”€ user ```
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then} ![](_images/_targets_objects.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## \_targets/
To display targets: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_read(model)[1] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` (Intercept) 12.6906 ``` ::: :::
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_read(model)[2] ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Date 0.0004374435 ``` ::: :::
::: notes - Well not strictly pure... - `.rds` is a R-specific format to save *any* type of object - Can be save and read with `saveRDS()` and `readRDS()` - Also should note that the pipeline is composition of pure functions. - Pure functions: - Referentially transparent function is a function that does not use any variable that is not also one of its inputs. - A function that does not interact in any way with the global environment. - Functions with only side-effects will be difficult to handle. For example, `base::plot()` ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## \_targets/
To load targets into the global environment: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_load(model) ``` :::



![](_images/tar_load_global_env.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Plots are different ::: {.callout-warning title="Advanced"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - A `target` must have a "physical" output. (Base plot produces side-effects... ğŸ¤’) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Luckily {`ggplot2`} produces plots as an output. ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - But we probably want to save them somewhere! ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} So we use `ggsave()` at the end of the plotting function: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} plot <- ggplot(...) ggplot2::ggsave(here::here("_outputs/ab_plot.png"), plot = plot) return("_outputs/ab_plot.png") ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - **NOTE**: We return the file path to keep {`targets`} happy ğŸ˜‡ :::
::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## File Big Brother

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} keeps track of changes in files and functions ğŸ•µï¸ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Any changes will result in the targets being identified as out-of-date ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - So, are re-computed (and their dependencies) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - We can visualise this... :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Code dependency graph
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_visnetwork(script = "_targets_analysis.R") ``` ::: ![](./_images/complete_code_dependency_graph.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Let's change something

::: {.fragment .fade-in} - We now filter out the years 2020 & 2021 ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} format_time_period <- function(data) { data |> ... |> dplyr::filter(!Date %in% c(2020, 2021)) } ``` ::: :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Let's change something
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_visnetwork(script = "_targets_analysis.R") ``` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in width="450" height="300"} ![](./_images/incomplete_code_dependency_graph.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;"} ::: ::: notes - The graph will also highlight in red if there is an error in the pipeline. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Steps skipped

::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_make() ``` :::
```{{r}} v skipped target data_file v skipped target nat_data > dispatched target nat_data_clean o completed target nat_data_clean [0.03 seconds] v skipped target model v skipped target plot > ended pipeline [2.5 seconds] ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## These can be embedded graphs...
```{mermaid} %%| label: mermaid-code-gph %%| eval: true %%| echo: false graph LR style Legend fill:#FFFFFF00,stroke:#000000 style Graph fill:#FFFFFF00,stroke:#000000; subgraph Legend direction LR xf1522833a4d242c5([Up to date]):::uptodate --- xd03d7c7dd2ddda2b([Stem]):::none xd03d7c7dd2ddda2b([Stem]):::none --- xeb2d7cac8a1ce544>Function]:::none end subgraph Graph direction LR xb1fbb690b4ec8c10>extract_year]:::uptodate --> xd20a83ce47f3194c>format_time_period]:::uptodate xf7d598eca7911241>round_to_multiple_five]:::uptodate --> xec203b5a68d60f72>plot_model]:::uptodate xd20a83ce47f3194c>format_time_period]:::uptodate --> xc2980a3d74445b80([nat_data_clean]):::uptodate x83c942fcaf37c3dc([nat_data]):::uptodate --> xc2980a3d74445b80([nat_data_clean]):::uptodate x0d01c84c9424364d([data_file]):::uptodate --> x83c942fcaf37c3dc([nat_data]):::uptodate x9242f8c59a209716>get_nat_absence_data]:::uptodate --> x83c942fcaf37c3dc([nat_data]):::uptodate x9043e9d6bef6a839([model]):::uptodate --> x667cd56a75e2bb2b([plot]):::uptodate xc2980a3d74445b80([nat_data_clean]):::uptodate --> x667cd56a75e2bb2b([plot]):::uptodate xec203b5a68d60f72>plot_model]:::uptodate --> x667cd56a75e2bb2b([plot]):::uptodate x12e88730e39644dc>fit_model]:::uptodate --> x9043e9d6bef6a839([model]):::uptodate xc2980a3d74445b80([nat_data_clean]):::uptodate --> x9043e9d6bef6a839([model]):::uptodate end classDef uptodate stroke:#000000,color:#ffffff,fill:#354823; classDef none stroke:#000000,color:#000000,fill:#94a4ac; linkStyle 0 stroke-width:0px; linkStyle 1 stroke-width:0px; ``` ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## ... or save them as a .html
::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} htmltools::save_html(html = targets::tar_visnetwork("_targets_analysis.R"), file = "_outputs/code_pipeline.html") ``` ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in width="450" height="300"} ![](./_images/errored_code_dependency_graph.png){style="border: 2px solid grey;" height="450" width="800"} ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Handling files
::: {.callout-warning title="Advanced"}
::: {.fragment .fade-in} - **MUST** use the data's file path initially (and `format = "file"`) ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_target( name = data, command = here::here("_data/1_absence_3term_nat_reg_la.csv"), format = "file" ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Then use the file path target to read in the data ğŸ“– ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} targets::tar_target( name = nat_data, command = read.csv(data) ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Otherwise, {`targets`} will not track the data (any changes to it) ğŸ˜´ :::
::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Parallel computation
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Can run any independent steps (*targets*) in parallel ğŸ”€ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - We are able to harness any GPU cores available, cutting computation time âœ‚ï¸ ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - {`targets`} knows which parts of the pipeline can be ran in parallel ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - To set this up... :::
::: notes - Also could be useful on DataBricks where more cores and nodes may be available. ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Parallel computation
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Need to load a few more packages: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(targets) library(future) library(future.callr) plan(callr) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Utilise the {`targets`} function to run in parallel: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} # Set workers = 2 to use 2 cpu cores targets::tar_make_future(workers = 2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} Simple as that! ğŸ’¥ :::
::: notes - Most of our laptops have around 7 cores. - Don't use all the cores though as some are needed for background computer stuff! ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Other features {.center} ğŸ”® ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## RMarkdown & Quarto
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Can include the rendering of a `.Rmd` or `.qmd` to the pipeline ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Utilises the power of the {`targets`} computation ğŸ”‹ :::
::: r-stack ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Load package needed ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} libray(tarchetypes) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} Function to render Quarto file in the pipeline ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_render( my_doc, "my_document.qmd" ) ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} How to load targets in the Quarto file ```{{r}} tar_read(plot) ``` ::: :::
------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## SQL
::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} - When executing code to SQL you will need to create connect and disconnect each time ğŸ”Œ ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} function(yml_key) { conn <- connect_sql_db(yml_key) on.exit(DBI::dbDisconnect(conn, shutdown = TRUE)) DBI::dbGetQuery(...)} ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} - Also the package {`sqltargets`} which applies {`targets`} principles to .sql files ğŸ“¦ ::: ::: r-stack ::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-out} ::: {.cell} ```{.sql .cell-code} -- !preview conn=DBI::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite()) -- tar_load(query_params) select id from table where age > {age_threshold} ``` ::: ::: ::: {.fragment .fade-in} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} tar_sql(query, path = "query.sql", query_params = query_params) ``` ::: ::: :::
::: notes - SQL connection repetitio is to ensure the connection is closed and is reusable ::: ------------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Key takeaways

::: {.fragment .fade-in-then-semi-out} - Enforces a modular, function based pipelines âœ…

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
